> Nice! Assuming that you actually need it... ;)

Most of the time a is.instanceOf(SomeException.class) is more than
enough. There are situations though when it makes sense to check, let
say for instance that an AccessDenied exception is thrown and that the
message contains the username you just passed to the loginMethod() (or
whatever).

If you want to check that the message contains the userName and the
required credentials then it makes sens to use an and exprssion with
two is.containg() constraints (you care that the information is there
but not in which order or about the wording of the message)

You could of course make two or three separate testcases for this with
different asserts if you don't like the .and() expressions. The point
is that constraints allow you to verify whatever you want on the
exception while @test{expect=<ExceptionClass>} can verify only that an
exception of a certain class is thrown.

if you combine the above with an assertThat(<value>, <constraint>)
method see http://joe.truemesh.com/blog/000511.html you have an
extremely powerful arsenal of asserting tools. I have personaly
stopped using the assertXxxx methods of jUnit in favour of assertThat.
